subject: Economics
title: Adam Smith: The Invisible Hand
description: A quick, practical guide to Adam Smith: The Invisible Hand.

hook.text: A Scottish professor wrote a book in 1776 that became the Bible of capitalism. He never used the word 'capitalism.'

buildup.text: Adam Smith's 'Wealth of Nations' argued that self-interest, not charity, drives economic prosperity for everyone.

discovery.text: The invisible hand: when a baker bakes for profit, the town gets bread.

twist.text: Smith also warned that businessmen conspire to fix prices and exploit workers.

climax.text: Smith's insight: markets coordinate millions of decisions without a central plan. No person designs it. It just works.

punchline.text: Capitalism's founder was also its first critic.

quiz.question: What is Adam Smith's 'invisible hand' concept?
options: Individual self-interest unintentionally creating broader social benefit through market forces
